statement.text: Venous hypertension is the sustained elevation of ambulatory venous pressure (>40 mmHg) that drives the pathophysiological cascade of chronic venous disease, leading to inflammation, skin changes, and ultimately venous ulceration.
statement.formal: Ambulatory_Venous_Hypertension: AVP > 40 mmHg during walking (normal: 20-30 mmHg)

explanation.intuition: When venous pressure remains elevated during walking, blood pools in the leg, stretching vessel walls, causing fluid leakage into tissues, and triggering an inflammatory cascade that damages skin and subcutaneous tissue over time.
explanation.key_insight: The severity of skin changes and ulceration risk correlates directly with the degree of ambulatory venous hypertension. Patients with AVP >80 mmHg have near-certain ulceration, while those with AVP <30 mmHg rarely develop skin changes.
explanation.technical_details: Venous hypertension causes capillary distension, widening of endothelial gaps, and extravasation of macromolecules including fibrinogen. Pericapillary fibrin cuffs impair oxygen diffusion. Leukocyte trapping in distended capillaries leads to activation and release of proteolytic enzymes and reactive oxygen species. This creates a chronic inflammatory state with tissue remodeling, liposclerosis, and ultimately ulceration.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Venous ulcers result from tissue ischemia similar to arterial disease. Reality: The mechanism is inflammatory, not ischemic, though oxygen diffusion is impaired.
Misconception: Superficial reflux alone causes severe venous hypertension. Reality: Combined superficial and deep disease causes the highest pressures.
Misconception: All patients with reflux develop venous hypertension. Reality: Adequate collateral drainage and muscle pump function can compensate for reflux.

presentation: Progressive skin changes starting with hemosiderin deposition (pigmentation)
Atrophie blanche (ivory white patches with telangiectasias)
diagnosis: Direct ambulatory venous pressure measurement (invasive gold standard)
Air plethysmography with venous filling index
Duplex ultrasound for reflux and obstruction localization
Venous Clinical Severity Score (VCSS) for quantification
treatment: Compression therapy (cornerstone - reduces tissue edema and supports muscle pump)
Deep venous reconstruction for obstruction (stenting, bypass)

definition.@value: The pathological state of persistently elevated venous pressure during ambulation, resulting from reflux, obstruction, or muscle pump failure, which initiates the inflammatory cascade leading to chronic venous disease manifestations.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy
AVF/SVS Guidelines on Management of Chronic Venous Disease

learning_objectives: Describe the pathophysiological cascade from venous hypertension to ulceration
Correlate ambulatory venous pressure levels with clinical severity
Identify the inflammatory mechanisms underlying skin changes
Apply treatment strategies targeting venous hypertension
clinical_pearls: AVP >80 mmHg virtually guarantees ulceration if untreated
The gaiter area is most affected due to maximal hydrostatic pressure
Compression works by reducing tissue edema and improving muscle pump efficiency
Fibrin cuff theory explains impaired oxygen diffusion in venous disease
Leukocyte trapping and activation is the key inflammatory trigger

medicalCode.description: Varicose veins of unspecified lower extremity with inflammation
